channel.title: 1. SSME Thermodynamic Data on CryoRocket.com
channel.description: Recent content in 1. SSME Thermodynamic Data on CryoRocket.com

item.description: MathJax = { tex: {inlineMath: [['$', '$'], ['\\(', '\\)']]} }; Figure 1.1.1: SSME Fuel System Schematic [1, 2] The SSME fuel system performs two functions: a. Route high-pressure hydrogen to the engine’s three combustion chambers. b. Route cryogenic hydrogen to regeneratively cool the walls of the combustion chambers and the nozzle jacket. Liquid hydrogen enters the Low Pressure Fuel Turbopump (Station 1) from the External Tank.

MathJax = { tex: {inlineMath: [['$', '$'], ['\\(', '\\)']]} }; Figure 1.2.1: SSME Oxidizer System Schematic [1, 2] The SSME oxidizer system routes high-pressure oxygen to the engine’s three combustion chambers. Liquid oxygen enters the Low Pressure Oxidizer Turbopump at Station 17 from the External Tank. This pump raises the pressure of the incoming fluid to a modest level before routing it to the High Pressure Oxidizer Turbopump (HPOTP) at Station 19 where the pressure is raised to a level suitable for combustion.

MathJax = { tex: {inlineMath: [['$', '$'], ['\\(', '\\)']]} }; Figure 1.3.1: SSME Combustion System Schematic [1, 2] The SSME Combustion System performs three functions: a. Power the SSME Fuel System. b. Power the SSME Oxidizer System. c. Generate thrust by expelling combustion products from the nozzle. Hydrogen and oxygen enter the Fuel Preburner at Station 29. In this chamber the propellants are mixed and combusted to form a hot gas consisting of approximately 90% hydrogen and 10% water vapor by mole fraction (shown in yellow on Figure 1.
